Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: How things are with her.
What do you mean by that?

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: Dr. Rush asked that I speak to you personally, Mr. Girard,
to make known to you certain surprising developments that have
only now come to our attention regarding the state or condition of your wife, sir.

Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: I do not know, sir, if you value your time, but I do mine.
Please be brief.

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: I will try.
May I sit, sir?

Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: By all means, sit or do whatever you wish, only let us get this bothersome business settled.
If there is some question as to the adequacy of the monthly payment of her expenses I shall naturally
increase the allotment to whatever sum is necessary,
although I will remind you that both you and Dr. Hutchinson assured me the amount settled on was more than sufficient.

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: Oh, no, Mr, Girard.
Let me assure you that it is not a question of costs.
The generosity of your settlement is well-known by all concerned in this matter.
No, the hospital could not wish for a more beneficial arrangement.
No sir, it is not a financial matter that brings me here but rather one concerning your wife's mental and... physical condition.

Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: As I am quite familiar with the one and not at all interested in the other,
I doubt that anything you have to tell me could be of the least interest to me.
Nonetheless, as she yet remains my wife, and as you have taken it upon yourself to interrupt my affairs with this matter,
I am willing to listen to you, only briefly.

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: I have rather surprising news for you and for all of us at the hospital.
Mrs. Girard is with child.

Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: Yes.

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: Do you mean, sir, you have been cognizant of that fact?

Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: I have.

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: And were you so aware when you had her brought to us?

Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: Yes, sir, I was.

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: And yet you brought her to us to be confined with the mentally insane?

Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: Most certainly.
I find it curious that I need point out to you that physical conditions have
nothing whatsoever to do with the state of one's mind.
I brought my wife to you because she is insane.
That has nothing to do with whatever physical condition she may be in.

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: Mr. Girard, I am happy to tell you that is not always the case.
Although it is true that the mind functions separately from the body which supports it,
there is one major exception to that general rule.

Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: And what is that?

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: The state of pregnancy.
It is not uncommon for a woman with child to exhibit many of the signs we ordinarilly ascribe only to the insane.
You see, many of the irregularities you spoke of are quite possibly
due to nothing more than the naturally flighty state of mind brought on in many women
by the physical changes in the female body during the pre-natal period.
When a woman is with child she is wont to have imaginings,
to suffer strange cravings,
certain outbursts of temper and language that one does not expect.
In other words, her behavior may become erratic in a fashion that is often alarming
to those who are used to a more sedate and stately behavior on the part of the lady.
Consequently, under these circumstances, the board of directors and I agree
that it is in everyone's best interest for you to remove Mrs. Girard from our care,
allow her the confinement usually recommended for the later stages of a pregnancy, and,
after her deliverance of your child, she will most probably prove to be as sane as she ever was.
What I am trying to tell you, sir, is the happy news that Mrs. Girard is quite possibly, even probably, as sane as you or I. (Pause.)

Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: My wife, sir, is insane.

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: Mr. Girard...

Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: (Interrupting.) I said, she is insane.
(Slight pause.)

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: Your wife suffers from severe headaches.
She is extremely nervous.
Upon occasion she has exhibited erratic behavior,
and outbursts of abusive language.
If she were not pregnant, there might be cause to think an extended rest,
close care, and quiet might not be enough to restore her normal faculties.
However, as she is with child...

Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: That is a fact I wish you and the members of the board to disregard.
Whether she is, as you say, with child or not need be no concern of yours.
Nor of anyone else's.
I tell you in all candor it is not a fact I wish ever be known.
Nor do I feel kindly disposed toward you, sir, for your having pressed this loathsome fact to my consideration.
True, I was previously aware of... her condition.
But I have chosen of my own free will to ignore it.
It is my wish, sir, that you and all the members of the board do likewise.

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: Sir, I am amazed.
I have just told you that your wife is soon to be delivered of your child,
a child you seem determined will be gestated and born in a madhouse,
amidst scenes of the most horrid chaos,
amongst madmen and madwomen,
and you advise me to ignore it?

Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: Precisely.

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: Mr. Girard, I am trying to tell you that
given these newly discovered circumstances we cannot permit you
to leave Mrs. Girard in these conditions.
Indeed, to place such woman in such surroundings at such a time
is to pose the greatest possible threat to her sanity,
no matter how sound of mind she might have been beforehand.

Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: I see. (He writes out a draft.)
Perhaps this will be suficient. (He hands the check out to MR. PHILLIPS, but PHILLIPS does not take it.)

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: Mr. Girard.
It is not a question of money, sir.

Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: Is that fact?

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: It is, sir.

Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: Come, come, sir.
I am a loyal and an active supporter of our new republic, and I am a businessman.
In both capacities it has been my experience
that everything in life is a question of money.
I have found no friendship, no love, no loyalty, and no fact
that cannot be altered by large enough draft or a tidy enough sum of money.

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: Surely you can't believe that, Mr. Girard.

Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: Believe it? I know it.
It is fact, sir. I have staked my career on it,
and, as you can see, I have prospered.
(MR. GIRARD thrusting the check at him.) Look at this!

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: (Taking the check.) Three thousand dollars.
But this is made out...

Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: To you, sir.
That is payment in advance which I hope you will be gracious enough to accept from me.
You see, I do not choose to be concerned any further with any
diffculties that may arise due to my wife's... confinement.
Therefore, I humbly ask that you personally see to it that
whatever needs to be done is done to keep all references to her,
her child, if it should live, and any other dificulties concerning her, beyond my awareness.
As to the board of trustees, tell them I will assume all responsibility for this matter,
in writing, of course.
Tell them, also, that within a month of my unfortunate wife's demise
the hospital shall receive a check identical to the one you hold now.
You need not ever mention this check.
I feel a man's finances are no one's affair but his own.
Tell them, also, that upon my death, I will bequeath
Pennsylvania Hospital no less a sum than ten times the amount written there.
All this, of course, to be above and beyond the sums already agreed to for her daily care,
and given in deepest gratitude for the superb treatment accorded the insane woman who unfortunately still bears my name.

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: I don't know what to say.

Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: Answer only this: can it be done?

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: Yes. (Lights.)

Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: Answer only this: can it be done?

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: Yes.

Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: Good! See to it then. I believe you know your way out?

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: But, sir...

Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: Sir?

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: What of the child?

Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: That, sir, is no concern of mine.

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: I would not have a child of mine born under such conditions for all the money in the world.

Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: And I can assure you, sir, neither would I.

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: Mr. Girard. Do you mean the child...

Lines.Speaker: Girard
Lines.Line: I bid you good day, sir.

Lines.Speaker: Phillips
Lines.Line: Sir. (Lights fade on GIRARD and PHILLIPS, FURIES set MARY free.)

Lines.Speaker: MARY.
Lines.Line: Bring him!
(GIRARD ENTERS. He does not know where is he for a moment. The FURIES surround him and then hide behind him.)

Lines.Speaker: GIRARD.
Lines.Line: How did you get here?

Lines.Speaker: MARY.
Lines.Line: I am where you placed me. Stephen.

Lines.Speaker: GIRARD.
Lines.Line: Where I... I shouldn't be in this place.

Lines.Speaker: MARY.
Lines.Line: (Laughing.) No, Stephen?

Lines.Speaker: GIRARD.
Lines.Line: No, I...

Lines.Speaker: MARY.
Lines.Line: (Laughing.) Do you think I'm a vision?

Lines.Speaker: GIRARD.
Lines.Line: No. Of course not. I... no.
(MRS. HATCHER ENTERS with MR. PHILLIPS.)

Lines.Speaker: MRS. HATCHER.
Lines.Line: Is it true as they say that the baby is that of Mary Girard's?

Lines.Speaker: MR. PHILLIPS.
Lines.Line: The baby's origin is a matter of no importance, Mrs. Hatcher.
You and Mr. Hatcher will receive the set sum for nursing the child
just as you have with all the other children you have cared for in the past.

Lines.Speaker: MRS. HATCHER.
Lines.Line: Yes, Mr. Phillips. I do appreciate you're calling on me again.
My health is ever so much better now than it used to be.

Lines.Speaker: MR. PHILLIPS.
Lines.Line: The past is past, Mrs. Hatcher.

Lines.Speaker: MARY.
Lines.Line: Why have you done this to me?

Lines.Speaker: GIRARD.
Lines.Line: I had no choice. You are insane.

Lines.Speaker: MARY.
Lines.Line: Don't lie to me, Stephen.
Even if I were insane you could have spared me this.
Both you and I know what my behavior was.
You know as well as I that I am sane.

Lines.Speaker: GIRARD.
Lines.Line: I hope that is true.

Lines.Speaker: MRS. HATCHER.
Lines.Line: Oh. Such a pretty little baby.
And a girl.
What is her name?

Lines.Speaker: MARY.
Lines.Line: Her name is Mary!

Lines.Speaker: MR. PHILLIPS.
Lines.Line: Call her whatever you wish. It is immaterial.

Lines.Speaker: MRS. HATCHER.
Lines.Line: Oh, I shall take good care of this one, Mr. Phillips.
There won't be no repeats of my old mistakes.
I'm ever so much better now.

Lines.Speaker: MR. PHILLIPS.
Lines.Line: I told you not to speak of the past, Mrs. Hatcher.
Both for your sake and for the sake of the Hospital
it is best if you keep hidden from your neighbors the source from which you've received this child.

Lines.Speaker: MRS. HATCHER.
Lines.Line: (Exiting.) Oh, I shall love having her.
I am truly grateful, I've never had a little girl before.
I think I'll call you... Rose.
Rose is my name, you see, and you will be my little girl.

Lines.Speaker: MR. PHILLIPS.
Lines.Line: (Calling after her.) Mrs. Hatcher!

Lines.Speaker: MARY.
Lines.Line: She told me you hated me like the devil.
I didn't believe her until this moment.

Lines.Speaker: GIRARD.
Lines.Line: Who told you that?

Lines.Speaker: MR. PHILLIPS.
Lines.Line: (Calling.) Mrs. Hatcher!

Lines.Speaker: MRS. HATCHER.
Lines.Line: (Returning.) Yes, Mr. Phillips?

Lines.Speaker: MR. PHILLIPS.
Lines.Line: Mrs. Hatcher.
I would caution you against becoming too fond of this child.
It is, after all, a child born under unpropitious circumstances.

Lines.Speaker: MRS. HATCHER.
Lines.Line: What do you mean, Mr. Phillips?

Lines.Speaker: NIR. PHILLIPS.
Lines.Line: I am asking you to treat it the same as you would any other child.

Lines.Speaker: MRS. HATCHER.
Lines.Line: Oh, I will sir.

Lines.Speaker: MR. PHILLIPS.
Lines.Line: Yes? Well, good.
Yes, I would have you treat it just though it were... a normal child.

Lines.Speaker: MRS. HATCHER.
Lines.Line: Isn't it a normal child, Mr. Phillips?

Lines.Speaker: MR. PHILLIPS.
Lines.Line: Oh, I didn't mean to alarm you, Mrs. Hatcher.
This baby seems normal, doesn't it?
It needs all the care and attention other children require.
Only there is a difference.

Lines.Speaker: MRS. HATCHER.
Lines.Line: What difference, Mr. Phillips? Tell me, please.

Lines.Speaker: MARY.
Lines.Line: Don't let him do this!

Lines.Speaker: MR. PHILLIPS.
Lines.Line: It's mother is a patient among the insane.

Lines.Speaker: MRS. HATCHER.
Lines.Line: Oh no!

Lines.Speaker: MR. PHILLIPS.
Lines.Line: The baby has been born by and among those possessed of devils.
(The FURIES dance.)

Lines.Speaker: MRS. HATCHER.
Lines.Line: God preserve us!

Lines.Speaker: MR. PHILLIPS.
Lines.Line: Born by and among those possessed of devils.

Lines.Speaker: MRS. HATCHER.
Lines.Line: God preserve us.

Lines.Speaker: MR. PHILLIPS.
Lines.Line: By and among those possessed of devils.

Lines.Speaker: MRS. HATCHER.
Lines.Line: God preserve us. (MRS. HATCHER and MR. PHILLIPS EXIT.)

Lines.Speaker: MARY.
Lines.Line: Is that what I am to you?
When we met I was sixteen,
a servant carrying water through the streets.
I laughed at everything then.
And I was happy without even knowing it.
Do you remember that girl, Stephen?

Lines.Speaker: GIRARD.
Lines.Line: She does not exist, madam.

Lines.Speaker: MARY.
Lines.Line: No. We destroyed her, you and I. Destroyed her utterly.
Didn't you ever love her?

Lines.Speaker: GIRARD.
Lines.Line: She was pretty. People noticed her.
She was innocent, a trait few women have.

Lines.Speaker: MARY.
Lines.Line: Innocent! And then she married you
and she thought she had gained the whole world,
and in reality gained only this little room.

Lines.Speaker: GIRARD.
Lines.Line: She had everything she should have wanted.

Lines.Speaker: MARY.
Lines.Line: The cost was too great.

Lines.Speaker: GIRARD.
Lines.Line: It cost her nothing.

Lines.Speaker: MARY.
Lines.Line: (Laughing.) Nothing! (She laughs.) What is the value of nothing, Mr. Girard?
What is its price? Can you estimate the enormity of nothing?
I can tell you it is beyond calculation.
I was prepared to give you everything, but you wanted only nothing.
So it, is fitting that you have placed me here in this room with nothing.

Lines.Speaker: GIRARD.
Lines.Line: You had everything a woman could reasonably have wanted.

Lines.Speaker: MARY.
Lines.Line: What good is reason without some little affection?

Lines.Speaker: GIRARD.
Lines.Line: If you wanted affection you should have told me
instead of making a public display of yourself.

Lines.Speaker: MARY.
Lines.Line: Stephen, I made no attempt to hide my behavior from you.
We differed in only one way. I didn't bring my lovers under your roof.
You cannot fault me for that. I always maintained a respect for you and a regard for your feelings and your pride.
Perhaps I should not have done the things I did. But in that I am not alone.
Don't lock me up in this poor house.
Send me away, Stephen. I will go wherever you wish.
Take me back to one of your houses and lock me in a room for the rest of my life.
Give me my father's tools, nails and harnmer, and I will drive the demons away from me.
Lock me in a room; allow me there to suffer my conscience and dream my dreams alone.

Lines.Speaker: GIRARD.
Lines.Line: Alone! A seclusive wife pleases no one.
The needs of my sex are fewer than those of yours, madam.
Men are more self-sufficient.
Consequently, it is all the more important for a man's wife to see to it that his needs are met.
Your acknowledgement of me as your husband never went beyond the duties of the flesh.

Lines.Speaker: MARY.
Lines.Line: You mean to say my thoughts were my own?

Lines.Speaker: GIRARD.
Lines.Line: I mean to say you failed to be a dutiful wife.
When I found you you were a peasant. Your mother remains one.
I had hoped you would develop a sense of who you had become in becoming my wife.
I had hoped you would rise above your origins sufficiently to modify an overly tolerant nature.
It is well known that the wife of Stephen Girard converses indiscriminately with persons of no consequence
as readily as she does with persons of some social standing.
In these ways, and others, you have failed me. (Pause.)

Lines.Speaker: MARY.
Lines.Line: Yes, you are right.
In these ways I have failed you, Stephen. (MARY turns from him and starts to exit.)

Lines.Speaker: GIRARD.
Lines.Line: If only you could...

Lines.Speaker: MARY.
Lines.Line: No!

Lines.Speaker: GIRARD.
Lines.Line: I can make your life a hell on earth, madam.

Lines.Speaker: MARY.
Lines.Line: When I was childless you blamed me.
I too thought, I was barren.
I felt I had cheated you out of a son.
But it wasn't me.
You couldn't put life in my body because you had none in your own.
I got more warmth from a stranger in a little hour than you could ever give.
It isn't my child that is loathsome to you, Mr. Girard, but the freedom of my mind and my love of life itself.
May God have pity on you, sir.

Lines.Speaker: GIRARD.
Lines.Line: God? (Pause. Very calmly.)
I do not know if God exists.
If I thought he did I would pray that he keep you here for ever so long a time.
As I cannot be sure of him, I will see to it myself that you endure a hell on earth.
And I will pray to a possible God that it may endure forever. (GIRARD EXITS.)

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: You’d really enjoy it Granddad

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: Oh, I don’t know.
I’d find it hard to keep track of who’s who and what’s going on.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: But that’s the beauty of this one.
Every episode is a different story
and they only last about 30 minutes.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: Anyway, I’ve gone off the TV.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: There’s a good one on late tonight.
It’s a story about a time when Bob Dylan visited a friend in London
and called to the wrong house.
I’ve seen it before.
You’re a big Dylan fan, you’ll love it.
I’ll record it and we can watch it together.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: Go on so. I can hardly stop you!

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: Right. Here we are. All to ourselves.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: There’s not many around today

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: I just want to drop these letters in the post box for Mam.
I’ll see if Mr. Softee is in his spot - grab a couple of 99s. Mums the word.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: I don’t need anything.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: When have you ever refused a 99?
You wait there. Feed the ducks. I won’t be long.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: Take your time.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: A mistake?

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: That’s all

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: So, she’s not /

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: No, she’s not.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: Are you sure?

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: Your daughter, Karen, my mother, is at home waiting for us.
Look. Here’s a photo of you and Mam.
It was taken at her birthday last June. See.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: But how could I …
(to Sarah) so, you’re not my daughter?

Lines.Speaker: Sarah
Lines.Line: I … I’m not Karen.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: See. It’s alright granddad.
We all make mistakes. Here’s a nice cold choc ice for you.
You have to promise not to tell mam.
She’ll kill me if she finds out that I gave it to you before dinner.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: I don’t feel like it.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: You better eat it while it’s cold.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: I’ll bring it home and eat it later

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: It’ll be all melted by then.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: Did you get one for yourself?

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: (Lying) I ate it on the way back.
You have yours now. It’ll cool you down.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: (to Sarah) I’m really, really sorry about that.

Lines.Speaker: Sarah
Lines.Line: It’s fine.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: He’s not normally as bad as this
but he’s gotten himself into a right state there.

Lines.Speaker: Sarah
Lines.Line: He said he was waiting for his wife.

Lines.Speaker: Sarah
Lines.Line: My grandmother died two years ago.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: I guessed that.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: Sometimes he remembers, but mostly, well …

Lines.Speaker: Sarah
Lines.Line: They must have been close.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: They had their moments but yeah … he was devoted to her.
He began to go downhill after she died.
Sounds like the two of ye had a great conversation.

Lines.Speaker: Sarah
Lines.Line: Yeah. I didn’t realise at first that he had … you know?

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: Most people never guess when they meet him.
He certainly hasn’t lost any of his charm.

Lines.Speaker: Sarah no
Lines.Line: ds, smiles.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: I hate seeing him like this.
He was … he is a fantastic grandfather.
He was like a father to me.
The one consolation is that he always knows who I am.

Lines.Speaker: Sarah
Lines.Line: Long may that continue.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: Sometimes he doesn’t recognise my mother.
It doesn’t happen that often
but I’ve never seen him mistake someone else for her.
I don’t think I’ll tell her. It might upset her.

Lines.Speaker: Sarah
Lines.Line: She’s better off not knowing.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: You know, you do have a look of my mother, the hair, the eyes. (He shows her photo on the phone) See.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: (Almost afraid to look) Yeah.
I can understand how he might confuse you. (Sarah nods, Pause)
My name is Ken by the way.

Lines.Speaker: Sarah
Lines.Line: Sarah.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: Yes, Sarah, that’s it. Wait ‘til I see.

Lines.Speaker: Sarah
Lines.Line: His book!

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: That was my idea.
Not sure if it does any good
but it gives him something to hang on to.

Lines.Speaker: Sarah
Lines.Line: He consults it a lot!

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: Yes, I knew it. Here we are,
Sarah Joyce, pretty girl, visiting.
And you say I’m forgetting things.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: (To Sarah) You see, a charmer.
Granddad, your choc ice!

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: I’ll put it in my pocket.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: But /

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: It’ll be grand.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: OK, whatever! (To Sarah)
At least he hasn’t opened the wrapper.

Lines.Speaker: Sarah
Lines.Line: That’s true!

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: Right, let’s get you home.

Lines.Speaker: Sarah
Lines.Line: (To Sarah) Apologies again and thanks for being so understanding.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: It was nice to meet him.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: She’s a nice girl.
She’s lost her father you know.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: (To Sarah) What’s that about?

Lines.Speaker: Sarah
Lines.Line: It’s nothing.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: She’s all alone.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: You certainly made an impact.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: It was nice to meet you Sarah and
thanks again for looking after the old man.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: Less of the old, you pup!

Lines.Speaker: Sarah
Lines.Line: Peter, it was … lovely to meet you (shakes his hand).
You mind yourself.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: You’ve made an old man happy.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: I thought you weren’t old?

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: I can say it, not you.
(To Sarah) It’s been a while since I got a hug from a pretty girl.
Thank you … (thinks) … Sarah.

Lines.Speaker: Sarah
Lines.Line: I’ll be off.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: Will you not stay for some dinner?

Lines.Speaker: Sarah
Lines.Line: What?

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: I’m sure Sarah has lots of other things to be doing.

Lines.Speaker: Sarah
Lines.Line: Just a bit of dinner. She’s all on her own.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: Thank you Peter but I’ve stayed too long as it is.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: Are you sure. You’d be most welcome

Lines.Speaker: Sarah
Lines.Line: I’m heading off this evening. I’m back in work tomorrow.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: If you’re ever back this way, feel free to call.
Ken could give you our address.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: Now Granddad. Sarah’s in a hurry.

Lines.Speaker: Sarah
Lines.Line: It is a beautiful place Peter
but I’ve seen everything I came here to see.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: Well, safe journey

Lines.Speaker: Sarah
Lines.Line: I’m not one for re-visiting things.
(Pause) I’ll be off.
Nearly forgot this. Bye!

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: Goodbye Sarah and thanks again.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: We’d better make a move.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: She was a nice girl.
You could do with a girl like that.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: I don't think I'm her type.
Right, let’s be off.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
Lines.Line: Ah! We forgot to feed the ducks.

Lines.Speaker: Ken
Lines.Line: Take it with you and you can feed them tomorrow.

Lines.Speaker: Peter
